turn.2: Since 1983 the return of foreign investment has been slow because of the high costs of rebuilding and a continuing perception of political uncertainty.
turn.4: Of the approximately twenty enterprises that had reopened by the late 1980s, most were import-export enterprises that lacked a formal relationship with the banking sector.

turn.6: Most Chadian-owned enterprises had managed to re-establish themselves.

turn.8: Yet by 1986, small enterprises that had assembled bicycles, motorcycles, and radios remained closed.
turn.10: The lack of access to credit was another impediment to business expansion in Chad.
turn.11: What happened with the banking system?
turn.12: Despite the reopening in 1983 of the Bank of Central African States (Banque des Etats d'Afrique Centrale—BEAC) and of two commercial banks, the International Bank for Africa in Chad (Banque Internationale pour l'Afrique au Tchad—BIAT) and the Chadian Credit and Deposit Bank (Banque Tchadienne de Crédit et de Dépôt—BTCD), the high proportion of available credit going to Chad's major industries limited credit available to smaller enterprises.
